547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/title|Digital flight-line aeromagnetic data sets of the Conterminous United States, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 02-0361
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|map scale 1:125,000, 14 sheets by D.S. McCulloch and R.H. Chapman The OFR maps state that the survey was "prepared in cooperation the California Division of Mines and Geology."
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication.) This data set was collected at a fixed barometric altitude of 2000 ft.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report. Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1976
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The survey way flown during July to September. We have assigned the value 186 since the day was not included in the file. Maximum error, therefore, is 91 days.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|313748
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|49602.05
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|50934.00
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at unknown intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field determined by an international committee about every five years (e.g., 1965, 1970, 1975, 1980, 1985). The International GRF (IGRF) is commonly used. After adequate acceptance, a model becomes the Definitive GRF (DGRF), which is the preferred field to remove. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF75. Datum 50680. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-2.00
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|1005.00
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 3101 Project name: California Coast, California Survey flown by: Airborne Geophysics Survey compiled by: GeoMetrics, Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 4037 Survey height: 2000 ft Altitude method: Constant barometric elevation Flight-line spacing: 1 mi Flight-line direction: NE-SW Aircraft used: Grumman Tracker S2F Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: Geometrics G-803 proton Sensor tow distance: unknown
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb1e4b0bdc51792f584.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. 547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 1000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1979
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|20011030

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|53364.00
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|54971.05
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at unknown intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF75 updated to the date flown. After removing the regional field the contractor added a datum of 53500 nT to the calculated magnetic values. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|53661.70
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|55219.05
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 3153 Project name: Marble Mountains, California Survey flown by: LKB Resources, Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 1055 Survey height: 1000 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.5 mi Flight-line direction: N60E Aircraft used: Cessna or Commander Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: unknown Sensor tow distance: unknown
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb2e4b0bdc51792f592.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Geological Survey

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 99-0440
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|Roberts, C.W. and Jachens, R.C. 14 pages
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 1000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1980
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|2667.2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|8858.1
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|51053.30
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|58020.3
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at unknown intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1975. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-1576.1
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|5069.3
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5aa.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.

Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 3750 Survey height: 1000 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.5 mi Flight-line direction: NE-SW Aircraft used: Navajo Chieftain Airport - arrival: Chico, CA Airport - departure: Chico, CA Magnetometer used: GeoMetrics G-803A proton precession Sensor tow distance: unknown

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|map scale 1:62,500
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried on the wingtip of the aircraft. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 1000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1981
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|52390.72
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|53686.83
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1975 updated. Datum 52570. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9eb3e4b0bdc51792f5b4.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.

Survey compiled by: QEB, Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 680 Survey height: 1000 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.5 mi. Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: Cessna Turbo-206 Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: Geometrics G-803 proton precession Sensor tow distance: 0

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 82-818C
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried on a "stinger" that was attached to the aircraft. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 400 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1981
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|3658.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|49518.41
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|49735.01
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF1975. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec0e4b0bdc51792f60c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Medicine Lake Highlands, California
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4084
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on 9-track magnetic tapes and were transferred to CD-ROM. Data processing took place on an HP workstation and a Dell personal computer running a Windows NT or XP operating system. Data were reformatted using the Geosoft, Inc., Oasis Montaj program.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubdate|1979
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Airborne electromagnetic Surveys of the Cascade Range, Western United States
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 83-092
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|by D.C. Fraser and D.B. Hoover 64 p., 30 sheets, map scale 1:24,000
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as in the radar and barom channels. Sometimes channels were added and filled with dummy values (-9999.9) to comply with the established format. Some records that had no usable data were deleted. The contractor database did not have flight line direction, year, day (jul_day), fiducial, barometric altimeter, or residual magnetics channels. -9999 or -9999.9 was inserted in the fiducial, barometric, and residual magnetic channels in order to conform to the established template. The lines were flown east-west and half were labelled as negative which probably indicated direction. However, all the data were oriented in the same direction so the actual direction could not be determined. A dummy value of -1 was used in the direction channel in order to conform to the established template. The survey was flown between January 25 and March 22, 1981. As no exact date was given in the data or the report, January 25 was chosen as the Julian day. There are no tie lines with this survey.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried in a "bird" towed by a helicopter. This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 170 ft. Because aircraft cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1975
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec1e4b0bdc51792f61e.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Often the digital data did not contain date information and only the month and year flown or just a starting date were stated in the written documentation. In these cases, the first day of the month or the date the survey began was used as the Julian date and added to the digital data. Other information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data were written in the format described in the section on Digital_Transfer_Information.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
