547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Bob Kucks, Pat Hill
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on CD_ROM's.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors may have been replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 800 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2002
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|200208
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ec2e4b0bdc51792f650.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4260 Project name: Salinas Valley, California Survey flown by: Goldak Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 1915 Survey height: 800 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.33 mi Flight-line direction: N40W Aircraft used: Piper Navajo PA-31 Airport - arrival: Salinas, CA Airport - departure: Salinas, CA Sensor tow distance: unknown Magnetometer used: Geometrics 822A cesium vapor Data recording interval: 0.1 second Regional field removed: IGRF 2000 or DIGRF

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Aeromagnetic anomalies and topography of the Cascades, N. California
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=CA23
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks. This survey was flown by the Geophysics Group of the Oregon State University under contract to the U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|198006

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Aeromagnetic anomalies and topography of the Cascades, N. California
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 82-198
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|map scale 1:250,000
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a fixed barometric altitude of 9000 ft.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1982
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ecfe4b0bdc51792f6ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Often the digital data did not contain date information and only the month and year flown or just a starting date were stated in the written documentation. In these cases, the first day of the month or the date the survey began was used as the Julian date and added to the digital data. Other information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data were written in the format described in the section on Digital_Transfer_Information.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 1,000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced. There are several suspicious areas with constant value (2496.7) in the radar channel, including line 5010.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1982
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|2496.7
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|barom
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|altitude above mean sea level, in feet, measured using the barometer that is part of the aircraft navigation system Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|2503.3
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|16637
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|53979.32
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|56420.21
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field determined by an international committee about every five years (e.g., 1965, 1970, 1975, 1980, 1985). The International GRF (IGRF) is commonly used. After adequate acceptance, a model becomes the Definitive GRF (DGRF), which is the preferred field to remove. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1975 updated to the period of flying. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-1986
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|935
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed0e4b0bdc51792f6fd.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.

Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 3640 Survey height: 1000 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.5 mi Flight-line direction: N-S Aircraft used: Cessna Turbo-206 Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: GeoMetrics Model G-803 Sensor tow distance: 0

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubdate|2012
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Blanca, Colorado
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4290
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|20031017
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/enddate|20031031
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/progress|complete
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/update|none planned
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/spdom/bounding/westbc|-105.67

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Bob Kucks, Pat Hill
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on CD_ROM's.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors may have been replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 450 ft. Because aircraft, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2003
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed1e4b0bdc51792f713.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|200908

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|197803

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Viki Bankey, David Daniels, Carol Finn, Pat Hill, Holly Hindle, Bob Kucks, Vicki Rystrom, Sarah Shearer Cooperating contributors from the National Geophysical Data Center are: Ronald Buhmann, David Dater, Susan McLean, Stewart Racey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on 9-track magnetic tapes and were transferred to CD-ROM. Data processing took place on an HP workstation and a Dell personal computer running a Windows NT or XP operating system. Data were reformatted using the Geosoft, Inc., Oasis Montaj program.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Geological Survey

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Miscellaneous Field Study

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|Flanigan, V.J. and others map scale 1:100,000
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey layouts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as in the radar and barom channels. Sometimes channels were added and filled with dummy values (-9999.9) to comply with the established format. Some records that had no usable data were deleted. The database did not have flight line direction (directn), year (year), Julian day (day), fiducial (fiducial), or radar altimeter (radar) channels. A dummy value of -1 was used in the directn channel in order to conform to the established template. The lines were renumbered (1-31) during USGS processing in order to conform to the established template. The values in the fiducial channel were generated based on latitude, using Oasis montaj. The values in the residual magnetics (resmag) channel were calculated based on the following formula: resmag=total magnetics (totmag) - DGRF It was found that the survey was flown from March-April, 1978. The first of March has been assigned as the date of the survey, but this does not reflect the actual date that each line was flown.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 300 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported. Unpublished products generated by USGS included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1978
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ed3e4b0bdc51792f74f.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Often the digital data did not contain date information and only the month and year flown or just a starting date were stated in the written documentation. In these cases, the first day of the month or the date the survey began was used as the Julian date and added to the digital data. Other information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data were written in the format described in the section on Digital_Transfer_Information. Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 02-0361
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|199411
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/enddate|199411
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/progress|complete

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|Hildenbrand, T.G., and Ravat, D. p. 567-585
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing. Data were taken from a UNIX file in a format developed by the U.S. Geological Survey to conserve processing resources. Post file format contains four total-field values correlated with a pair of latitude and longitude coordinates, year, day (YYYY.DDD). Extent of typical editing (i.e. drop-outs, spikes) performed before the creation of the .pos file is unknown and varied by individual.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9. The original contractor database did not have a fiducial (fiducial) channel. The values in the fiducial channel were generated based on latitude using Oasis Montaj.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried on a tail "stinger" that was attached to the aircraft. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 500 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1994
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|4370
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|226.4
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|899.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|885.8
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|1706.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|54034.95
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|55056.36
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 0.1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. The temporal variations cannot be completely predicted, thus error arises in the application of the IGRF reductions. These errors cannot be evaluated until the release of the DGRF, a minimum of five years after the IGRF release. This field is issued to best describe the configuration of the earth's past magnetic field. Accuracy of the DGRF calculations is dependent on the quality of the survey data and sensitive to changes in air pressure. Through processing experimentation and experience, USGS personnel found that significant flight altitude changes produced small changes (0.01-0.03 nT) in DGRF values regardless of the altitude source used (e.g. radar altimeter, barometric altimeter). If radar altimeter data are complete, a terrain channel was calculated using Oasis Montaj DAP (Data Access Protocol), USGS 1:250,000 terrain data, or USGS 15 second terrain data. DAP is the easiest to use but suffers from inconvenient dummy values at sea level. In such cases, 15 second terrain data was used. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1990. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-399.01
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|659.19
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4163 Project name: Wabash Valley, Illinois Survey flown by: Geonex Aerodat, Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 3800 Survey height: 500 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.28 mi Flight-line direction: N65W Aircraft used: Cessna Titan 404 Airport - arrival: Harrisburg, IL Airport - departure: Harrisburg, IL Magnetometer used: Scintrex cesium vapor, optically pumped Sensor tow distance: approximately 11.5 ft (3.5 meters)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7b9.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. 547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Louisiana Bayou
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4275
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|20021011

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors may have been replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 500 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2002
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee1e4b0bdc51792f7c0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|200208

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 02-0361
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|map scale 1:24,000 72 pages, 46 sheets The OFR includes a note that the survey was flown "in cooperation with the U.S. Department of Energy and Michigan Technical University"
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|This is survey part 1 of 2. The second part of the survey can be found under Jacobsville Contact North, Michigan, Project #4036B. The survey was separated based on flight line direction (#4036A was flown in a variable flight line direction, and #4036B was flown in a N-S direction). Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9. A dummy value of -1 was used in the flight line direction (directn) channel in order to conform with the space allotted in the established template. The original contractor database had no date (jul_day), flight line direction (directn), barometric altimeter (barom), or total magnetic field (totmag) channels. This survey has been flown with a variable flight line direction. As a result, the exact azimuth is not included in the database and the channel has been filled with dummy values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried in a bird towed on a line that was approximately 200 feet below the aircraft. The bird as it is towed is slightly behind the aircraft and therefore the vertical distance between the magnetometer and the aircraft is slightly less than the length of the line but remains constant for the survey. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 400 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1980
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1.0 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1975. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-1521
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|2293.7
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4036A Project name: Jacobsville Contact South, Michigan Survey flown by: High Life Helicopters, Inc. Survey compiled by: QEB Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 924 Survey height: 400 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.25-0.5 mi Flight-line direction: variable Aircraft used: Aerospatiale Lama 315B Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: Geometrics G-803 nuclear precession Sensor tow distance: 200 ft
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee2e4b0bdc51792f7db.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. 547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.
