547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Viki Bankey, David Daniels, Carol Finn, Pat Hill, Holly Hindle, Bob Kucks, Vicki Rystrom, Sarah Shearer Cooperating contributors from the National Geophysical Data Center are: Ronald Buhmann, David Dater, Susan McLean, Stewart Racey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on 9-track magnetic tapes and were transferred to CD-ROM. Data processing took place on an HP workstation running a Windows NT operating system. Data were reformatted using the Geosoft, Inc., program Oasis Montaj version 4.3.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubdate|1999
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Digitized Aeromagnetic Datasets of the Conterminous United States, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|raster digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 99-557
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|CD-ROM or online files Complements this publication with analog data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1999/ofr-99-0557/
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Data acquisition was delayed due to A/C downtime, magnetic storms, and inclement weather. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9. Directn channel was added and filled with dummy values, -1, to comply with the established format. The original line numbers have been multiplied by 10 to distinguish segments of lines. The original contractor channel labelled scan has been renamed as fiducial. Because these three surveys were combined into one, the rawmag and totmag fields are not compatible across surveys due to the disparity magnetic field changes over the two years in which the surveys were flown. The DGRF was removed which allowed a more consisten leveling of all the units. Some of the E-W linear features may be a result of flight lines that cross one another and are not perfectly compensated. These were maintained in the database because they may be useful as individual profiles. Much cultural noise is visible as high-frequency anomalies scattered throughout the survey. The blank area in the north-central region is a power station which generated unrealistic magnetic values which were removed.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation. Tests were also conducted of a LORAN system similar to the following description: Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using aircraft navigational aids such as line-of-sight electronic systems that measure the distances from each of two ground stations to the aircraft using microwave or radio transmitters.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried in a special housing that was attached to the right wingtip of the aircraft. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 1000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|200212
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|53077.56
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|55498.20
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 0.5 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. The temporal variations cannot be completely predicted, thus error arises in the application of the IGRF reductions. These errors cannot be evaluated until the release of the DGRF, a minimum of five years after the IGRF release. This field is issued to best describe the configuration of the earth's past magnetic field. Accuracy of the DGRF calculations is dependent on the quality of the survey data and sensitive to changes in air pressure. Through processing experimentation and experience, USGS personnel found that significant flight altitude changes produced small changes (0.01-0.03 nT) in DGRF values regardless of the altitude source used (e.g. radar altimeter, barometric altimeters). If radar altimeter data are complete, a terrain channel was calculated using Oasis Montaj DAP (Data Access Protocol), USGS 1:250,000 terrain data, or USGS 15 second terrain data. DAP is the easiest to use but suffers from inconvenient dummy values at sea level. In such cases, 15 second terrain data was used. For this survey, the field removed was the DGRF. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-450.50
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|1262.85
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 1143, 1146, 1147A Project name: New Madrid '90, '91, '92, Missouri, Arkansas, and Tennessee Survey flown by: U.S. Geological Survey Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 8348 Survey height: 300-500 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.25 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: Fairchild Porter PC 6/C-H2 Airport - arrival: Sikeston, MO Airport - departure: Dyersburg, TN Magnetometer used: Geometrics G-113 proton precession Sensor position: right wing-tip
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee3e4b0bdc51792f7ed.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. 547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Viki Bankey, David Daniels, Carol Finn, Pat Hill, Holly Hindle, Bob Kucks, Vicki Rystrom, Sarah Shearer Cooperating contributors from the National Geophysical Data Center are: Ronald Buhmann, David Dater, Susan McLean, Stewart Racey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on 9-track magnetic tapes and were transferred to CD-ROM. Data processing took place on an HP workstation and a Dell personal computer running a Windows NT or XP operating system. Data were reformatted using the Geosoft, Inc., Oasis Montaj program.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubdate|1980
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Aeromagnetic map of the east-central Midcontinent of the United States
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|Nuclear Regulatory Commission Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|NUREG/CR-1662
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Washington, D.C.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|National Technical Information Service
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|by R.W. Johnson and others scale about 1:2,000,000
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|There were numerous brief dropouts most of which were easily corrected by interpolation. Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as in the radar and barom channels. Sometimes channels were added and filled with dummy values (-9999.9) to comply with the established format. Some records that had no usable data were deleted. The month and year were stated in the published paper. The first day of July was used as the Julian day.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 1000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1977
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ee4e4b0bdc51792f7fb.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Often the digital data did not contain date information and only the month and year flown or just a starting date were stated in the written documentation. In these cases, the first day of the month or the date the survey began was used as the Julian date and added to the digital data. Other information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data were written in the format described in the section on Digital_Transfer_Information.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as the radar and barom channels. The original data did not have radar altimeter (radar) or barometric altimeter (barom) channels. Line 1.1 was renamed line 60, and line 55.1 was renamed line 61 in order to make a distinction from lines 1 and 55, respectively. Residual magnetic values were adjusted on the following lines to eliminate obvious datum shifts within or between lines: Line number Shift (nT) 4 +20 9 +10 16 +15 29 +20 30 +10 48 +25 50 +18 51 +16 52 +14 53 +7 54 +5
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 500 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1975
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|barom
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|altitude above mean sea level, in feet, measured using the barometer that is part of the aircraft navigation system Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|53795.61
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|55681.55
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at unknown intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. Temporal variations cannot be completely predicted, thus error arises in the application of the IGRF reductions. These errors cannot be evaluated until the release of the DGRF, a minimum of five years after the IGRF release. This field is issued to best describe the configuration of the earth's past magnetic field. Accuracy of the DGRF calculations is dependent on the quality of the survey data and sensitive to changes in air pressure. Through processing experimentation and experience, USGS personnel found that significant flight altitude changes produced small changes (0.01-0.03 nT) in DGRF values regardless of the altitude source used (e.g. radar altimeter, barometric altimeter). If radar altimeter data are complete, a terrain channel was calculated using Oasis Montaj DAP (Data Access Protocol), USGS 1:250,000 terrain data, or USGS 15 second terrain data. DAP is the easiest to use but suffers from inconvenient dummy values at sea level. In such cases, 15 second terrain data was used. For this survey, the field removed was the DGRF 1975 calculated using the date and DAP terrain data added to an altitude datum of 152 meters (500 feet). Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-785.25
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|1122.48
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef1e4b0bdc51792f85d.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/origin|Smith, B.D., Cannia, J.C.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubdate|2008
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Ashland HEM data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|vector and raster digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|2008-1018
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2008/1018/
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4313
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|This report is a digital data release for a helicopter electromagnetic and magnetic survey that was conducted during March 2007 in three 93-square-kilometer (36-square-mile) areas of eastern Nebraska as part of a joint State of Nebraska and U.S. Geological Survey study. The objective of the survey is to improve the understanding of the relationship between surface-water and ground- water systems critical to developing water resource management programs. The electromagnetic equipment consisted of six different coil-pair orientations that measured electrical resistivity at separate frequencies from about 400 hertz to about 115,000 hertz. The electromagnetic data were converted to electrical resistivity geo-referenced grids and maps, each representing different approximate depths of investigation for each area. The range of subsurface investigation is comparable to the depth of shallow aquifers. The three areas selected for the study, Ashland, Firth, and Oakland, have glacial terrains and bedrock that typify different hydrogeologic settings for surface water and ground water in eastern Nebraska. The geophysical and hydrologic information from U.S. Geological Survey studies are being used by resource managers to develop ground-water resource plans for the area.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Improve the understanding of the relationship between surface-water and ground-water systems critical to developing water resource management programs.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/sngdate/caldate|2008
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef2e4b0bdc51792f86f.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|19991110
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/enddate|19991216
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|website: http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2001/ofr-01-0145/
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9. Line numbers were changed to conform to the template.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried on a "stinger" that was attached to the aircraft. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 500 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1999
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time. Value of -99999 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|588955
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|878005
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|242.4
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|2870.7
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|barom
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|altitude above mean sea level, in feet, measured using the barometer that is part of the aircraft navigation system Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|5973.3
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|10262.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|49992.17
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|53072.51
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 0.1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF1995. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-934.51
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|2151.75
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4233 Project name: Bodie-Aurora, California and Nevada Survey flown by: Sander Geophysics, Ltd. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 12710 Survey height: 500 ft Altitude method: draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.093 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: Britten Norman Islander or Cessna Caravan Airport - arrival: Yerington, NV Airport - departure: Yerington, NV Magnetometer used: Scintrex or GeoMetrics optically pumped cesium vapor Stinger length: approximately 8.2 ft (2.5 m)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9ef6e4b0bdc51792f8d0.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. 547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4288
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 450 ft. Because aircraft cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2003
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f06e4b0bdc51792f962.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|19830202

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using aircraft navigational aids such as line-of-sight electronic systems that measure the distances from each of two ground stations to the aircraft using microwave or radio transmitters.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a fixed barometric altitude of 6,000 ft. There are several areas in the radar and barom channels that have constant values. Minimal editing was performed.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1983
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|95
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|31
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|Both beginning and end julian dates were taken from dataset.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|183
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|11440
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|1811.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|2211.3
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|barom
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|altitude above mean sea level, in feet, measured using the barometer that is part of the aircraft navigation system Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|5600.3
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|6758.4
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|53697.5
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|55641
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field determined by an international committee about every five years (e.g., 1965, 1970, 1975, 1980, 1985). The International GRF (IGRF) is commonly used. After adequate acceptance, a model becomes the Definitive GRF (DGRF), which is the preferred field to remove. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1975. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-614.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|821.77
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4107 Project name: West-central Oregon, Oregon Survey flown by: Diversified Technical Services, Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 1230 Survey height: 6,000 ft Altitude method: Constant barometric elevation Flight-line spacing: 3 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: Hunting-Pembroke Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: Redmond, OR Magnetometer used: Geometrics Model 803 H.P. Sensor tow distance: unknown
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f13e4b0bdc51792f9e1.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. 547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Johnson City, Tennessee and North Carolina
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4286
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
