547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Bob Kucks, Pat Hill
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on CD_ROM's.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors may have been replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 1000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2003
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f14e4b0bdc51792fa36.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|201208

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|Schulz, Karen; 3 pages, 4 sheets map scale 1:50,000
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing. The flight lines for this survey were visually separated during data processing based on changes in latitude and longitude coordinates. The coordinates recorded while the plane was turning were removed to ease processing and standardization.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|There are no tie lines for this survey. Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9. Directn and barom channels were added and filled with dummy values, -1 and -9999.9 respectively, to comply with the established format. During processing, some spikes were removed from the total magnetic (totmag) channel.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 500 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1974
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|31
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|Contractor specified month but not day flown. Julian day was assigned as the first day of the known month. Maximum error, therefore, is 31 days. OR Both beginning and end julian dates were taken from dataset.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|233
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|673
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|barom
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|altitude above mean sea level, in feet, measured using the barometer that is part of the aircraft navigation system Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|49201.50
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|49753.45
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field determined by an international committee about every five years (e.g., 1965, 1970, 1975, 1980, 1985). The International GRF (IGRF) is commonly used. After adequate acceptance, a model becomes the Definitive GRF (DGRF), which is the preferred field to remove. For this survey, the field removed was the unknown. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 3062 Project name: Freer, Texas Survey flown by: Geodata International, Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 1570 Survey height: 500 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 1 mi Flight-line direction: NW-SE Aircraft used: unknown Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: proton precision Sensor tow distance: 0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f15e4b0bdc51792fa3a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as in the barometric altimeter (barom) and total magnetic field (totmag) channels. A dummy value of -1 was used in the flight line direction (directn) in order to conform to the established template. Line 190 is missing from the database.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried in a bird towed on a line that was approximately 50-100 feet below the aircraft. The bird as it is towed is slightly behind the aircraft and therefore the vertical distance between the magnetometer and the aircraft is slightly less than the length of the line but remains constant for the survey. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 400 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1980
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1975 updated to the period of flying. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-1828.1
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|2987.7
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4091 Project name: Beaver Valley, Utah Survey flown by: High Life Helicopters, Inc. Survey compiled by: QEB Inc. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 900 Survey height: 400 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.33 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: Aerospatiale SA Lama 315B Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: Geometrics G-803 Sensor tow distance: 50-100 ft
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f20e4b0bdc51792fa9c.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on 9-track magnetic tapes and were transferred to CD-ROM. Data processing took place on an HP workstation running a Windows NT operating system. Data were reformatted using the Geosoft, Inc., program Oasis Montaj version 4.3.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubdate|1979
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Aeromagnetic map of Pendleton and vicinity, Oregon and Washington, OFR 79-278
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 79-278
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|map scale 1:125,000 The OFR map has a processing explanation stating: Datum: 56,108.15 gamma A regional trend of 6.42 gamma/mile north and 4.37 gamma/mile east existed and was removed using the 1975 IGRF updated to 1976.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as the radar and barom channels. The original contractor database did not have radar altimeter (radar), barometric altimeter (barom), or flight line direction (directn) channels. A dummy value of -1 was used in the directn channel in order to conform to the established template. The values in the fiducial channel along lines 58-64 and tie lines 1001 and 1002 were generated based on latitude using Oasis montaj, in order to conform to the established template.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 500 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1976
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|55031
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|58141
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1975 updated to 1976. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-1324.81
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|1969.56
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f21e4b0bdc51792fabe.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Columbia River, Washington and Oregon
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4265
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|20020115

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/progress|complete
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/update|none planned

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on CD_ROM's.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors may have been replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter, barometric altimeter, and GPS. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried in a "stinger" attached to the tail of the aircraft. This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 750 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2002
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|201301
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4265 Project name: Columbia River, Washington and Oregon Survey flown by: Goldak Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 2610 Survey height: 750 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.25 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: Piper Navajo PA-31 Airport - arrival: Astoria, OR Airport - departure: Astoria, OR Sensor tow distance: stinger length unknown Magnetometer used: Geometrics G-822A cesium vapor Data recording interval: 0.1 second Regional field removed: IGRF 2000
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2ee4b0bdc51792fb46.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/pubdate|2012
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Mt. Adams, Washington
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4272
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|20020508

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors may have been replaced with the value -9999.9.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 200 ft. Because aircraft cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|2002
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|201208
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f2fe4b0bdc51792fb4a.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4272 Project name: Mt. Adams, Washington Survey flown by: Fugro Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 62 Survey height: 200 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.155 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: SA315B Lama helicopter Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Tow cable length: 100 feet Magnetometer used: Geometrics 822 cesium vapor Data recording interval: 0.1 second Regional field removed: IGRF

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Not all flight-line data have been released to the public because of lack of personnel to reformat data and service the requests. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. Digital flight-line data used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|by Bracken, R.E. and Nicholson, S.W. one CD-ROM
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as the barom channel. The values in the original barometric altimeter (barom) channel were invalid and replaced with dummy values -9999.9 during USG processing. The line numbers (line_no) have been modified. Originally the values were 5 integers numbers (770-2271) and exceeded the allocated space. Tie line 10002 was reset to 2000. Tie lines 20010-20071 were reduced by 18,000 and renumbered to tie lines 2010-2071.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short-period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) The magnetometer was carried on a wing pod that was attached to the aircraft. This data set was collected at a draped survey having a average terrain clearance of 1000 ft. Because aircraft, especially airplanes, cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1999
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 4.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data file was written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|fiducial
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|radar
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in feet An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|self evident

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|feet
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|56149.44
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|58156.38
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 0.1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed was the IGRF 1995. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|55243.97
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|57249.07
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4222 Project name: Wisconsin Eastern Shore, Wisconsin Survey flown by: High-Sense Geophysics, Ltd. Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 3500 Survey height: 1000 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.5 mi Flight-line direction: N-S Aircraft used: Cessna 206 Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Magnetometer used: Geometrics G-822A optically-pumped Cesium split beam Sensor tow distance: 0

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f32e4b0bdc51792fb84.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Each record contains the following 11 attributes: No abbrev.name contents 1 line_no flight line number 2 directn flight line direction, azimuth degrees from north (integer) 3 longitud longitude (decimal degrees) 4 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 jul_day Julian day flown (integer) 7 fiducial fiducial number (integer) 8 radar radar altimeter reading above ground (feet) 9 barom altitude above mean sea level (feet) 10 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 11 resmag residual magnetic value (nT)

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Southeast Wisconsin
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|tabular digital data
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=WI12
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|197503
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/enddate|197504
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/update|none planned
