547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Viki Bankey, David Daniels, Carol Finn, Pat Hill, Holly Hindle, Bob Kucks, Vicki Rystrom, Sarah Shearer Cooperating contributors from the National Geophysical Data Center are: Ronald Buhmann, David Dater, Susan McLean, Stewart Racey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on 9-track magnetic tapes and were transferred to CD-ROM. Data processing took place on an HP workstation and a Dell personal computer running a Windows NT or XP operating system. Data were reformatted using the Geosoft, Inc., Oasis Montaj program.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|Wisconsin Geological and Natural History Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubdate|1998
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Flight-line gridded aeromagnetic data for Kenosha, Racine, and Walworth Counties, southeastern Wisconsin
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|Wisconsin Geological and Natural History Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 1998-6
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Madison, Wisconsin
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|Wisconsin Geological and Natural History Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|By M.G. Mudrey, Jr. 2 p., 1 CD-ROM
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with the value -9999.9, such as in the radar and barom channels. Sometimes channels were added and filled with dummy values (-9999.9) to comply with the established format. Some records that had no usable data were deleted.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using aircraft navigational aids such as line-of-sight electronic systems that measure the distances from each of two ground stations to the aircraft.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected at a fixed barometric altitude of 2000 ft.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not reported to the USGS. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes, a map of residual or total field magnetics, and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1985
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes and values of -9999.9 were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected. Other errors in the data were not corrected. Horizontal positions were converted to latitude and longitude if the original values were UTM meters. Elevations were converted from meters to feet (1 m = 3.2808 ft). Often the digital data did not contain date information and only the month and year flown or just a starting date were stated in the written documentation. In these cases, the first day of the month or the date the survey began was used as the Julian date and added to the digital data. Other information was added that was missing from the data file but was recorded elsewhere. The reformatted data were written in the format described in the section on Digital_Transfer_Information.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|200212

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: WI12 Project name: Southeast Wisconsin Survey flown by: Mobil Survey flown for: Mobil Approx. no. of line miles: 1230 Survey height: 2000 ft Altitude method: Constant barometric elevation Flight-line spacing: 0.5 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: unknown Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Sensor tow distance: unknown Magnetometer used: unknown Data recording interval: unknown Regional field removed: unknown
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3de4b0bdc51792fba5.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eadetcit|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1. 547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Geological Survey, Department of the Interior, the National Geophysical Data Center, U.S. Department of Energy

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/title|Aeromagnetic and aeroradiometric data for the Conterminous United States and Alaska from the National Uranium Resource Evaluation (NURE) Program of U.S. Department of Energy
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 2009-1129
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic and aeroradiometric data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field and radiometric values and locations. The magnetic data set presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values. Geologic symbols or codes are also included. The geologic symbols were picked from surficial geologic maps. The radiometric data set presents latitude, longitude, altitude, geologic symbols or codes, apparent Uranium (Bismuth 214), Thorium (Thallium 208), and Potassium (K 40), the element ratios, and ancillary information.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks. Aeroradiometric surveys measure the radiation emanating from the earth's surface, which provides general estimates of the geographic distribution of uranium, thorium, and potassium in surficial and some bedrock units. Bismuth 214 and Thallium 208 are decay products of Uranium and Thorium. Along with Potassium 40 they give identifiable peaks in the gamma-ray spectra of naturally occurring radiation. The element data and the ratios of the element data are used to help map surficial geology and to detect concentrations of radioactive minerals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Department of Energy through Bendix Corp. contracted numerous airborne surveys over a period from 1974 to 1981 covering most of the conterminous United States and much of Alaska. The primary purpose was to obtain airborne radiometric data in order to locate and evaluate uranium resources. Aeromagnetic data were also acquired at the same time. In the mid-1980's, all the NURE Program's data were given to the U.S. Geological Survey. The aeromagnetic data were also archived at the National Geophysical Data Center. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Much of the digital flight-line data have been released to the public through a companion DVD and a web site. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. The original analog flight-line profiles used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file. CD's have been released containing the original radiometric flight-line data in various formats. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/datacred|These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Pat Hill, Bob Kucks, Rick Saltus, Ron Sweeney, Sarah Shearer Cooperating contributors from the National Geophysical Data Center are: Ronald Buhmann, David Dater, Susan McLean, Stewart Racey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/native|These data were originally recorded on 9-track magnetic tapes and were transferred to CD-ROM. Data processing took place on a Dell personal computer running a Windows XP operating system. Data were reformatted using the Geosoft, Inc., program Oasis Montaj version 6.3.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|4 sheets, map scale 1:250,000 Author: Oak Ridge National Laboratory
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, radiometic crystal packages, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with one of the Following values: -9999.9, -999.9, -99, etc. Sometimes channels were added and filled with dummy values (-9999.9, etc.) to comply with the established format. Records that had no usable data were deleted.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery: The horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data was determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Barometric altimeter data are not available for most of these data sets. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). The magnetometer was mounted on the side of the helicopter.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic and radiometric values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Conversion processes, if reported, may be found in the U.S. Department of Energy's published GJO- or GJBX- reports for the quadrangle or group of quadrangles. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1977
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 6.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Positioning and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes. Values of -9999.9,-999.9, -99.9, etc., were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected or, in some cases, the whole record was removed. Information that was missing from the data file but recorded elsewhere, such as year flown, was added th the file. The radiometric data were not checked for errors except for dummy values which were replaced with -99.9, -999.9, etc. The reformatted data files were written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in meters An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists, p. 89.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|30.5
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|648.3
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|meters
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Records containing missing data were usually deleted.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|51095.1
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|54033.8
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 2 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields. For this survey, the field removed is IGRF 1965. Some contractors add a constant to the residual value in order to avoid negative values. This constant can vary from one data set to another. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|53612.2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|55947.8
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|diurnal
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Base magnetometer values used to correct the total magnetic value. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time called the diurnal. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. The diurnal is monitored during the survey and if changes are severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|-9999.9
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3ee4b0bdc51792fbcf.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The base magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 2-4 second intervals.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Cochise-Dragoon, Arizona
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|analog contour map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=0003
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. In the earlier days of surveying, the only way to represent this data was to generate an analog map with contour lines. This dataset is a representation of the digitized contour lines either by following the lines or by choosing the intersection of the contour and flight-line to create a value of the magnetic field. The values presented are latitude, longitude, and map magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/othercit|by W.J. Dempsey and others map scale 1:62,500
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data shown on the original map have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data on the original map were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey layout specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Data is complete as reasonably digitized from the original map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the processors using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not documented. Products may include some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1963
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f3fe4b0bdc51792fbf2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS digitized original map to ASCII format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the ASCII digitized data and create raster JPEG images.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Cabeza, Arizona
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|analog contour map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=3090
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. In the earlier days of surveying, the only way to represent this data was to generate an analog map with contour lines. This dataset is a representation of the digitized contour lines either by following the lines or by choosing the intersection of the contour and flight-line to create a value of the magnetic field. The values presented are latitude, longitude, and map magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|197507

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/title|Aeromagnetic map of the Cabeza area, Arizona
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data shown on the original map have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data on the original map were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey layout specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Data is complete as reasonably digitized from the original map. Values are IGRF65 corrected with 49463 nT added back.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the processors using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not documented. Products may include some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1980
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS digitized original map to ASCII format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the ASCII digitized data and create raster JPEG images.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/spref/horizsys/geodetic/ellips|Clarke 1866
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/spref/horizsys/geodetic/semiaxis|6,378,206.4

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4ce4b0bdc51792fc27.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 3090 Project name: Cabeza, Arizona Survey flown by: Aerial Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 2213 Survey height: 4000 ft Altitude method: Above sea level Flight-line spacing: 1.0 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: Cessna 320 Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Sensor tow distance: unknown Magnetometer used: Mark IV magnetometer Data recording interval: unknown Regional field removed: IGRF65 with 49463 nT added back.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/title|Aeromagnetic and aeroradiometric data for the Conterminous United States and Alaska from the National Uranium Resource Evaluation (NURE) Program of U.S. Department of Energy
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/serinfo/issue|OFR 2009-1129
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/pubplace|Denver, CO
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/lworkcit/citeinfo/pubinfo/publish|U.S. Geological Survey
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic and aeroradiometric data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field and radiometric values and locations. The magnetic data set presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values. Geologic symbols or codes are also included. The geologic symbols were picked from surficial geologic maps. The radiometric data set presents latitude, longitude, altitude, geologic symbols or codes, apparent Uranium (Bismuth 214), Thorium (Thallium 208), and Potassium (K 40), the element ratios, and ancillary information.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. Aeromagnetic anomaly maps are important tools in mapping surficial and buried igneous rocks. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks. Aeroradiometric surveys measure the radiation emanating from the earth's surface, which provides general estimates of the geographic distribution of uranium, thorium, and potassium in surficial and some bedrock units. Bismuth 214 and Thallium 208 are decay products of Uranium and Thorium. Along with Potassium 40 they give identifiable peaks in the gamma-ray spectra of naturally occurring radiation. The element data and the ratios of the element data are used to help map surficial geology and to detect concentrations of radioactive minerals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/supplinf|The U.S. Department of Energy through Bendix Corp. contracted numerous airborne surveys over a period from 1974 to 1981 covering most of the conterminous United States and much of Alaska. The primary purpose was to obtain airborne radiometric data in order to locate and evaluate uranium resources. Aeromagnetic data were also acquired at the same time. In the mid-1980's, all the NURE Program's data were given to the U.S. Geological Survey. The aeromagnetic data were also archived at the National Geophysical Data Center. With the improvement in digital communication and the ability to store and transmit large data sets, the USGS is now able to release the flight-line data in a common format. The U.S. Geological Survey has contracted or flown numerous airborne surveys over a long period (1950's to present). Much of the digital flight-line data have been released to the public through a companion DVD and a web site. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file. A companion CD-ROM/web site has been released containing magnetic data that were generated by digitizing analog maps. The original analog flight-line profiles used to create the analog maps are unavailable. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file. CD's have been released containing the original radiometric flight-line data in various formats. Reference is in the Cross-Reference section of this metadata file.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, radiometic crystal packages, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors were replaced with one of the Following values: -9999.9, -999.9, -99, etc. Sometimes channels were added and filled with dummy values (-9999.9, etc.) to comply with the established format. Records that had no usable data were deleted.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery The horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data was determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Barometric altimeter data are not available for most of these data sets. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). The magnetometer was carried in a bird towed on a line about 100 feet below the aircraft. The bird as it is towed is slightly behind the aircraft and therefore the vertical distance between the magnetometer and the aircraft is less than the length of the line but remains constant for the survey.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic and radiometric values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices. Details are found under Attribute Accuracy Report, Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Conversion processes, if reported, may be found in the U.S. Department of Energy's published GJO- or GJBX- reports for the quadrangle or group of quadrangles. Unpublished products generated by the contractor included magnetic tapes and perhaps some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1978
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS reformatting of contractor data to standard format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj version 6.3 by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Positioning and magnetic values were checked for obvious errors or spikes. Values of -9999.9,-999.9, -99.9, etc., were given where the value could not be reasonably corrected or, in some cases, the whole record was removed. Information that was missing from the data file but recorded elsewhere, such as year flown, was added th the file. The radiometric data were not checked for errors except for dummy values which were replaced with -99.9, -999.9, etc. The reformatted data files were written in the format described in the section on Entity_and_Attribute_Overview.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|A fiducial number is a mark which indicates points of simultaneity. It is a user-defined integer used during airborne operations to correlate recording devices (magnetometers) with navigational records (altimeters, camera film, strip charts) that were recorded at the same time.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|radar altimetry reading, in meters An aircraft navigational system in which short electromagnetic waves are transmitted, and the energy scattered back by reflection is detected. From this measurement, the distance between the aircraft and the ground is calculated and recorded as radar altimetry. Values of -999.9 indicate missing data.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|454.8
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|meters
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|totmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Raw magnetic value with base magnetometer corrections applied. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. If changes are more severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Records containing missing data were usually deleted.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|54565.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|60574.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 1 second intervals.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmag
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|residual magnetic value The total magnetic value minus a geomagnetic reference field (GRF), which is a long-wavelength regional magnetic field. The most commonly used reference field is determined from a model developed by the International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy (IAGA). The International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF), is a predictive model adopted at the beginning of a model period (e.g. in 1989 for 1990-1995). After the model period, a revised definitive model is adopted, the DGRF. This is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields for epochs when CM models are not available. For this survey, the field removed is either IGRF 1965 or 1975. Some contractors add a constant to the residual value in order to avoid negative values. This constant can vary from one data set to another. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|-3135.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|2722.0
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The Geomagnetic Reference Field that was subtracted from the total magnetic value is based on a model, which was updated to the date of the survey. New models are available at five year intervals. These models have varying degrees of accuracy in determining the local reference field.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|diurnal
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|Base magnetometer values used to correct the total magnetic value. Because the magnetic field of the earth varies diurnally, a stationary base magnetometer is maintained on the ground during airborne surveying. The base magnetometer records changes in the magnetic field (in nanoTeslas) as a function of time called the diurnal. The magnetic changes may have an amplitude of 20 to 50 nanoTeslas. The diurnal is monitored during the survey and if changes are severe, as would occur from a magnetic storm, surveying is discontinued or the data recorded are not used. Diurnal variations are then removed from the airborne magnetic data based on the common time. Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|see: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1, p. 83-87. A description of magnetometers and how they measure the total magnetic field can be found in: Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, p. 505-517.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommin|51433.2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/rdommax|57553.7
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdomv/rdom/attrunit|nanoTeslas
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrva|2
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrvai/attrvae|The airborne magnetometer is accurate to about 1 nanoTesla, and the base magnetometer has the same accuracy. The accuracy of the base-corrected airborne value therefore is near 2 nanoTeslas or better.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrmfrq|The base magnetometer has a recharging interval of 0.5 seconds. The data were recorded at 2-4 second intervals.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrlabl|resmagCM4
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdef|The total magnetic field value minus the core component of geomagnetic field is known as the comprehensive model (CM). CM4 (the fourth generation of CM) is the modern reference field determined from a long-wavelength spatially and temporally continuous model of the geomagnetic field that simultaneously considers the Earths core, lithospheric, and external magnetic fields (external ionospheric and magnetospheric fields and the components induced by them inside the Earth). Spherical harmonic degree 13 of CM4 is the preferred model to use for removing regional magnetic fields for the time periods it is valid for (1960 to June 2002). Values of -9999.9 indicate missing data.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/detailed/attr/attrdefs|Ravat, D., T. Sabaka, A. Elshayat, A.Aref, E. Elawadi, R.P. Kucks, P. Hill, J.D. Phillips, C.A. Finn, C. Bouligand, R. Blakely, 2008, A Preliminary Full Spectrum Magnetic Anomaly Database of the United States With Improved Wavelengths for Studying Continental Dynamics, Invited Paper, Eos Trans. AGU, 89(53), Fall Meet. Suppl., Abstract GP52A-02. Sabaka, T.J., Olsen, N., and Langel, R.A., 2002, A Comprehensive Model of the Quiet-Time Near-Earth Magnetic Field; Phase 3: Geophysical Journal International, v 151, no. 1, p. 32-68.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 6085 Project name: Butte Quadrangle Survey flown by: Texas Instruments, Inc. Survey flown for: DOE Grand Junction Office Approx. no. of line miles: 2738 Survey height: 400 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 3 miles Flight-line direction: East-West Aircraft used: Sikorsky S58T helicopter Airport - arrival: Butte, MT Airport - departure: Butte, MT Magnetometer used: proton precession Sensor tow distance: 100 feet Radiometric crystal package volume: 3072 (down) & 512 (up) cu. in.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Aeromagnetics Each record contains the following 13 attributes: No name contents 1 line flight line number 2 fid fiducial number (integer) 3 time time (hhmmss) 4 day Julian day flown (integer) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 7 longitude longitude (decimal degrees) 8 radalt radar altimeter reading above ground (meters) 9 totmag corrected magnetic value (nT) 10 resmag residual magnetic value (nT) 11 diurnal ground magnetometer value (nT) 12 geology surficial geology beneath flight line (coded) 13 resmagCM4 resmag calculated using the comprehensive model (nT)
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f4fe4b0bdc51792fc86.xml|/metadata/eainfo/overview/eaover|Radiometrics Each record contains the following 21 attributes: No name contents 1 line flight line number 2 fid fiducial number (integer) 3 time time (hhmmss) 4 day Julian day flown (integer) 5 year year flown (integer) 6 latitude latitude (decimal degrees) 7 longitude longitude (decimal degrees) 8 radalt radar altimeter reading above ground (meters) 9 resmag residual magnetic value (nT) 10 geology surficial geology beneath flight line (coded) 11 qual quality flags of the radiometrics (integer) 12 app_K apparent Potassium as Potassium 40 (percent potassium) 13 app_U apparent Uranium as Bismuth 214 (parts per million equivalent uranium) 14 app_Th apparent Thorium as Thallium 208 (parts per million equivalent thorium) 15 U_Th_ratio ratio of Uranium and Thorium 16 U_K_ratio ratio of Uranium and Potassium 17 Th_K_ratio ratio of Thorium and Potassium 18 total_count total count of radioactivity (counts/second) 19 atmos_BI214 atmospheric Uranium as Bi214 (counts/second) 20 air_temp air temperature (degrees Celsius) 21 air_press air pressure (mmHg)

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|analog contour map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=1019
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. In the earlier days of surveying, the only way to represent this data was to generate an analog map with contour lines. This dataset is a representation of the digitized contour lines either by following the lines or by choosing the intersection of the contour and flight-line to create a value of the magnetic field. The values presented are latitude, longitude, and map magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data shown on the original map have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data on the original map were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey layout specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Data is complete as reasonably digitized from the original map. The central portion of the map between 34 and 35 was not digitized. That area is covered by digital project #4024, Needles.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the processors using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not documented. Products may include some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1975
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f57e4b0bdc51792fc88.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS digitized original map to ASCII format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the ASCII digitized data and create raster JPEG images.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=3027
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. In the earlier days of surveying, the only way to represent this data was to generate an analog map with contour lines. This dataset is a representation of the digitized contour lines either by following the lines or by choosing the intersection of the contour and flight-line to create a value of the magnetic field. The values presented are latitude, longitude, and map magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data shown on the original map have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data on the original map were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey layout specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Data is complete as reasonably digitized from the original map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the processors using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not documented. Products may include some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1976
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcba.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS digitized original map to ASCII format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the ASCII digitized data and create raster JPEG images.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/origin|U.S. Geological Survey and the Department of Interior

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Palen area, California
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|analog contour map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=4102
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. In the earlier days of surveying, the only way to represent this data was to generate an analog map with contour lines. This dataset is a representation of the digitized contour lines either by following the lines or by choosing the intersection of the contour and flight-line to create a value of the magnetic field. The values presented are latitude, longitude, and map magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|1955

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data shown on the original map have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data on the original map were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey layout specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Data is complete as reasonably digitized from the original map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the processors using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not documented. Products may include some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1985
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f58e4b0bdc51792fcc4.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|USGS digitized original map to ASCII format. USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the ASCII digitized data and create raster JPEG images.

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/title|Airborne geophysical survey: Modoc South-Central, California
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/geoform|analog contour map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/citation/citeinfo/onlink|http://mrdata.usgs.gov/magnetic/show-survey.php?id=CA03d
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/abstract|Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. In the earlier days of surveying, the only way to represent this data was to generate an analog map with contour lines. This dataset is a representation of the digitized contour lines either by following the lines or by choosing the intersection of the contour and flight-line to create a value of the magnetic field. The values presented are latitude, longitude, and map magnetic-field values.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/descript/purpose|Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/begdate|1957
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/timeinfo/rngdates/enddate|1957
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/timeperd/current|ground condition
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/progress|complete
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/status/update|none planned

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/origin|California Division of Mines and Geology

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/geoform|map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/idinfo/crossref/citeinfo/serinfo/sername|California Division of Mines and Geology Open File Report

547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/attracc/attraccr|The data shown on the original map have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. For example, position is listed as latitude and longitude, but these values were derived from the raw navigation data depending on the system used. (see notes under horizontal accuracy). Line numbers were added to records, and unusable data at flight-line ends were discarded (as aircraft slowed and turned around). Separate recordings were correlated by time and assigned to the correct location. The exact accuracies of these processing steps may not be known. They are discussed in the sections on attribute or positional accuracies.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/logic|The data on the original map were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey layout specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/complete|Data is complete as reasonably digitized from the original map
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/horizpa/horizpar|Flight Path Recovery Horizontal position of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined by reconciling down-looking photographs (recorded on continuous-strip film) with topographic maps and orthophotoquadrangle maps. Fiducial numbers and marks, impressed on any paper strips that were recording data or added to magnetic tape records, were included as a function of time to further reconcile location with instrumentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/posacc/vertacc/vertaccr|The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdesc|Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the processors using industry standard practices. Details are found under Horizontal_Position_Accuracy_Report, and Vertical_Position_Accuracy_Report Unless noted, conversion processes were not documented. Products may include some written documentation.
547613d1e4b0825061420548|547c9f5ae4b0bdc51792fcd2.xml|/metadata/dataqual/lineage/procstep/procdate|1966
